intro: Scleranthus perennis, commonly known as the perennial sand-verbena, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Amaranthaceae family and is characterized by its erect, branching stems and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in disturbed areas such as roadsides and fields. Its leaves are narrow and often covered in fine hairs, and it produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are usually pink or white. Scleranthus perennis is adapted to harsh environments and is considered a hardy, drought-tolerant species.
